awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Symphony of Smoothing and Change Point Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
A sudden change in a real life process is often of particular interest since the change may signal an anomaly, the onset of a disease, or an out-of-control process. What has been ignored in the literature is the co-existence of a slowly-changing component that also needs to be properly modeled to make valid statistical inference. In traditional statistics, inferring a sudden change and modeling a slowly-changing trend are often perceived as two seemingly conflicting concepts since they emphasize respectively on continuity and discontinuity of the true underlying process. Motivated by real-life applications, this project aims to develop three sets of novel statistical methods where simultaneous modeling of the sudden change and the slowly-changing trend are properly introduced to accommodate the practical needs. The statistical analysis tools developed in this project will benefit practitioners in the fields of cybersecurity, environmental sciences, financial managements, and medical studies. The results from the project will be integrated into teaching and student training, and be disseminated through publications and the distribution of R packages.

This project aims to the development of statistical methods that are natural fusions of change point analysis and nonparametric smoothing. The proposed method will combine recent developments in functional data analysis and nonparametric smoothing inference, such as functional time series and functional Bahadur representation, and change point analysis tools to solve the challenging problems. The first aim of the project focuses on change point detection in variance functions along with a smoothly-changing mean trend. A novel subsampling approach will be designed to incorporate the large sample size involved. The other two aims of the project are to develop change point detection methods and derive corresponding optimal theoretical properties for multivariate probability densities and functional time series, respectively.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our era of information explosion sees a lot of data with complicated structures that call for novel integration of statistical methods traditionally viewed as belonging to conflicting domains. Motivated by real-life studies, this project aims to integrate the knowledge in two of such "conflicting" statistical domains. Specifically, monitoring the viability status of a transplant organ requires a procedure to detect any anomaly in the surface temperature profiles, segmentation of seizure signals from multi-channel EEG records needs a precise procedure to pinpoint the seizure periods, and defense against hacker attacks requires accurate modeling of their attacking patterns. The statistical methods developed from the project provide a suite of analysis tools for researchers or practioners in the related scientific fields. These methods are either completely new for the relevant problems or can be considered as more flexible alternatives to the existing ones due to their weaker model assumptions. The developed analysis tools, available through requests to the PI, provide useful extension to the existing software, such as the R packages assist, gss, np, and crs. Two patents have been filed based on the research products from the project, one of which has already generated royalties from its usage by other researchers.

The proposal has stimulated the successful creation of a new graduate student course, STAT 5554 Functional Data Analysis, by the PI at his institution. The success of the proposal has also promoted students' interests in other relevant statistical courses at the PI's institution. These courses include Time Series, Survival Analysis, High Dimensional Data Analysis, Longitudinal Data Analysis, and Advanced Regression Methods. The training provided by the courses has been producing motivating students who can further research and applications in these fields. For example, the PI has supervised two PhDs in Statistics during the project period. Both students are working as Senior Statisticians at industries, respectively for a pharmaceutical company and a technology company. All the results from the project have been disseminated through journal articles and presentations at national and international meetings.
